testimony: This is the continuation of the Amnesty Committee session held in Cape Town.  The Panel consists of myself, Denzil Potgieter, I am assisted by Advocates Bosman and Sigodi.  We will be hearing the amnesty application this morning of Mr Yekwani in respect of the incident concerning Mr Jack.  Now I want the parties to place themselves on record.  I'm going to start with Mr Riley for the applicant, can you just place yourself on record.  Can you just, there's a red button on that microphone.
Yes, if you can just rewind.
Mr Chairperson, Members of the Committee, I confirm that I act on behalf of Mr Yekwani in this application for amnesty.
Thank you Mr Riley.  And then I think Mr Toyise.  Mr Toyise are you going to participate in the proceedings, are you going to represent your own interests at the hearing?
I am only going to participate when the need comes.
The answer is "I am going to participate when it is required".
Yes there might be something wrong with my headset.  I'll use my colleague's one and just see if it works.  Yes, can you just repeat that?
Mr Toyise said he is only going to take part when he is required to do so.
Yes thank you and then you'll be representing your own interests?  You don't have a lawyer in other words, who will be assisting you, you will be handling the matter yourself?
There is a gentleman next to me I think he is going to help me.
Oh, Mr Williams?  Alright, Mr Williams perhaps then we should go to you and you can put yourself on record and just confirm who you are representing in these proceedings?
Thank you Mr Chairperson.  The name is Peter Williams, I'm acting on behalf of certain implicated and interested parties namely Mr Gladstone Ntamo ...(intervention)
Just go a bit slower Mr Williams, I just want to make a note of that.  Just a minute.  Mr Ntamo you say, and who else?
As well as the ANC Western Cape.  Mr Chairperson I must say that this particular hearing has certain implications for the ANC and that is why the ANC approached me to represent them herein.
Yes, I don't know if Mr Toyise's view has taken you by surprise?
It has Mr Chairperson.  I haven't consulted with Mr Toyise and Mr Chairperson I'm going to have difficulty in acting on behalf of Mr Toyise given the fact that I haven't consulted with him.

Yes I don't know whether he's - perhaps I should just clarify it with him but he hasn't in so many words actually said that you were his lawyer, he was just sort of saying that.  Perhaps there's some assistance forthcoming from you, perhaps I should just clarify that with him because at this stage you don't haven't any formal instructions you say in respect of Mr Toyise's matter?
Yes very well.  Mr Toyise, have you listened to what Mr Williams told us now?

Yes he says that he isn't really here today to assist you, in fact he hasn't spoken with you about this case and so on and he might have some problems to help you so you understand that, did you follow that?
Yes now what is your position, how are you going to - are you able to look after your own interest or what?
I do not see any problem on my side as I do not have a legal representative.

Well if there is a difficulty you let us know and we will see what we can do about that but that will then be the position at the moment.  Mr Williams, I think we've got your clients then on record?  And then Advocate Ismail?
Mr Chairperson, Members of the Committee, the name is Ismail Jamie, I represent the Jacks family.
Yes Mr Jamie, sorry.  And then Ms Patel?
Thank you Honourable Chairperson, Ramula Patel, leader of evidence.
Thank you.  Yes, I think we've got the appearances.  Yes Mr Riley, is there anything else that you want to put on record or do you want us to administer the oath to your client?
I have nothing further. You may proceed Honourable Chair.
Thank you Mr Chairperson.  Mr Yekwani, where are you originally from?
I was born in Doordricht but I was staying in Whittlesea at ...(indistinct).
And where did you have your schooling?
In Whittlesea the name of the school Funda.
And tell us when did you become involved with the African National Congress?
I joined CACOR in 1985 here in Cape Town.
And can you tell us how you then - what you did after you in fact joined CACOR?
After I joined I decided to also join the underground structure so that I could be able to operate there.
Why did you want to join the underground structure?
My aim was to try and protect the community because I could see what was happening.  The government in those days was killing the people so I wanted to protect the community.
And where precisely were you based as part of the underground structure?
Were you under any person in particular's command at the time?
Yes at the time I had a commander.
And where was he at that time?
He was also present at KTC where at the same unit.
Do you recall how many persons were in your unit at that time?
I cannot say for sure when it comes to the number but the unit was also composed of people from Bekweni, it was not only people from my area.
And apart from Dax was there any other persons of the ANC that you had to report to?
Yes there were other people like Mr Ntamo, he was one of the commanders in the area.
What role did he play?   Mr Ntamo, what was his role?
He was a community leader and even in the SDUs we regarded him as the commander.

Now in the time that you were in the underground structure and in the time that you were part of the SDUs where did you obtain your weaponry from to execute any tasks that you were supposed to execute?
I used to borrow the firearm from Mr Ndamo.

Can you just explain to us today precisely what the arrangement was between yourself and Mr Ntamo insofar as that particular weapon was concerned?  What I'm trying to ascertain from you is did you if you borrowed the weapon on a particular occasion did you keep it with you the whole time or did you have to take it back to him or how did it work.
Sometimes I would take it back to him but sometimes I would keep the weapon with me if there was something else to be done.
Did you yourself ever personally own an R4 rifle?
I never owned a rifle, any rifle.

Now you explained to us that you got involved with the SDUs to protect the community and because what was happening in the country at the time.  Was anyone giving any specific instructions as to whatever missions were to be accomplished by your particular unit?
No, there were no instructions in our unit, we used to take initiative taking into consideration the situation at the time.
And what was your specific targets at that particular point in time?
Our aim was to fight the police.

Now did you in fact if you did decide to go on a particular mission or execute a particular task against the police and/or the authority, did you in fact tell Mr Ntamo or any of the commanders where you were in fact going to make a hit or execute a mission?

No, I never used to tell him but whenever I was taking a firearm from him I used to tell him that I was going to patrol, that's all he knew.  I just said I was going to look for police because it was well known that the police were the enemy.
And did he know what your attitude and feelings was towards the police?
Could you please repeat the question?
Did he know what your attitude was, what your feelings were to the police at that point in time?
Yes I can say he was aware that I used to hate policemen because he knew what the police did to me when I was arrested.

Now won't you be kind enough and tell us - so it would appear then that from what you're saying to us that you basically although Mr Ntamo was present there and there were various other commanders there within the area, there was no specific reporting to them about what was going on and you were basically operating in a very unsupervised fashion, would you say that would be correct?
Yes that is true, I used to report after the incident, I never used to report before the operation.
And what was the reason for not reporting before the incident?

I was scared because he would tell a person about a mission and when you get there the police would be there waiting for you so I was trying to avoid that, that is why I did not want to report before the mission.

Now you were provided with firearms or with a firearm by Mr Ntamo.  Is it correct that prior to the incident that resulted in the death of Mr Jack that you in fact were sent to jail for a period of time?
For burning the house of a policeman in Guguletu.
And you were sentenced to five years imprisonment, is that correct?
Yes it was five years but I only spent two years and six months inside.
Now prior to your being incarcerated prior to you going to jail did you ever undergo any specific training for military purposes?
And after your release from prison how did you feel about what happened to you, the fact that you had been in jail, how did you feel?
I was released and I had told myself that I was going to go ahead with my battle to hit the police.
And where did you in fact go and stay after that?
I went back to KTC where I used to stay before.
Did you stay with anyone in particular?
Yes I was staying with someone, Comrade Dax, but when I came from prison he had passed away and there was another gentleman who was staying with me.
Now did you report to any particular person then, you know on a daily basis about your activities?  Did you see any particular person about what you would do within the course of the day?
No, the only person that I would tell him about my activities was a comrade, the one that was staying with me, not anyone else.
Now won't you tell us prior to the killing, death of Mr Buyiswa Jack were you involved in any particular missions of note that you can recall?
Yes the other missions, I can still remember the other incident that took place in Khayelitsha.
Can you explain to us today how it came about, what was the cause of you going out on the night in question which resulted in the Jack?
We made a decision as for comrade, myself, Ntandaso and Michael and Tobani.
It was after realising what was done that the police were harassing the SDUs looking for firearms and we were not satisfied.
Mr Yekwani, just repeat those names please?  Yourself and who else?
And who are these other people?
Tobani, Michael and Ntandaso.  I'm the fourth person.
Who are they?  Were they part of your unit?  What role did they play?
Two of them, Michael and Ntandaso belonged to Brown's Farm branch, that was ANC Youth League.
Tobani used to tell us that he used to belong to a unit in Paarl and when he came to the area and I also involved him in my own unit.
That was for the very first time for me and him to work together.  Yes it's the same with them also.
Now did anything in particular happen at Khayelitsha immediately prior to the incident of Mr Pro Jack's death that resulted in you deciding to go out on that particular night?

What made us to go out on that particular night, there was an incident in Khayelitsha, there had been an incident whereby people were arrested and we were awoken at Brown's Farm and we were told that Mr Toyise was arrested with a firearm.
Anything else?  Did anything else happen?
Yes there were other incidents, things that were done by police because ...(indistinct) about eight people who were shot in one day.
Were they killed or were they just shot?
They were killed by the police.
Is it fair to say therefore that on the night that you then decided to go out again that you were going basically out to take revenge against the authorities, the police?
As it used to be my duty to keep guard on police.
I just want to check with you, after your release from prison, did you in fact receive any military training after that?
I got training after shooting at police in Khayelitsha.
Was that prior to the death of Mr Jack?
Where did you receive your training?
And who was responsible for training you?
Fatty who was an MK member, an ANC member.
Now how long did you undergo this training?
I told them that six weeks was enough because I had no time to go across the borders to acquire training.
So if we can get back to the incident, can you tell us, it was yourself and Tobani, Michael and Ntandaso.  What did you decide to do on that particular night?

We decided upon fighting the police who were arresting the people, disarming the people and shooting the people.  We realised that we had enough weapons.  Rather than waiting for the police to come and confiscate our weapons, we decided that it would be better for us to go out and fight them.
I had an R4 rifle, Tobani had a 38 special.  Michael had a Mosback.
I do not know that firearm but it was used by the special police.
Was it a rifle or handgun or what?
I can say it was a rifle but not an automatic one.
What did it shoot, what kind of ammunition did it shoot?
I used to call that pellets because it releases something like pellets at the same time, a lot of pellets at the same time.
Yes I can say so because I used my own language, I didn't know it in English.
What did the other person have, did the other person have a firearm?
I cannot remember very well when it comes to Michael's firearm but I remember Michael and Tobani.
Now can you tell us where you went to and why you decided to go to that particular place?
I had seen before that as we were looking for the van we wanted to see if we cannot get a van, a vehicle.
A police van I take it you're referring to now?

Yes I'm talking about a police van.  We decided to go to Lansdowne Road because we knew that there was one coming from Nyanga Police Station and from Philippi and Khayelitsha.  I know that they would take a turn at Lansdowne Road.
So you placed yourselves strategically then at that corner there?  Where precisely were you in that area?

At Lansdowne Road next to a turn that goes to Nyanga Station and there's another street that is going towards Philippi and there are trees next to the road and I'm the one who decided to stand next to that tree because I wanted to be the first one to attack.
And what was the weather conditions like?
It was a bit misty on that evening.
And approximately what time was it when you decided to go out there?
When I arrived there it was before ten because the van that we were expecting was to go past there at about ten when the police are changing shifts.
Yes, won't you be kind enough and explain what happened further?

As we were standing there facing the Philippi direction and I knew that it was time and the van was on the way, I heard comrade Sevani saying to me there was a car behind me, that is when I decided to turn and fire because I had no other option when he told me that there was a car behind me and I knew that those were police, they were coming either to arrest me or shoot me.  I turned and I fired.  As I am a left handed person, I turned and I pointed the firearm straight to the driver's window.  I pulled the trigger.

Do you recall how many shots you discharged?
Do you recall how many shots you fired?
I knew this R4 was an automatic, I did not count because the rifle was automatic.
What then happened?  You were firing at the motor vehicle?
I fired and I wanted to be sure that the car is not moving until we take cover and I also wanted to make sure that no one gets out of the vehicle.
It doesn't appear as if you in fact then looked who the occupants of the vehicle was before you were in fact started firing?

I did not notice at the time but I just looked and I saw that there were people inside the car at the front of the car when I was shooting but I did not take a closer look to see as to what kind of people were there.
So at the time then sir when you were firing the shots at this motor vehicle there and persons in the motor vehicle, who did you think you were firing the shots at?
I was sure that that was my enemy, the police that is.
After you had fired the shots at the motor vehicle as you say you wanted to make sure that this motor vehicle didn't move away from the scene there again, what then happened?
I fired and after that we crossed the road, we went to a squatter camp called Brown's Farm.
Now just before we move off to Brown's Farm now, at the time that you were firing the shots can you say whether your other comrades in fact were also firing shots at the motor vehicle or not?
I cannot say for sure because I was also disturbed by the noise that was coming from my own firearm, I cannot say that they did not shoot but I am certain that I did fire.
Yes I am sure that I did fire.
Do you recall how you were in fact dressed on that particular night?
Would you be kind enough and explain?
We went to a place as we had decided before the mission, we went to that particular place and they asked the comrades as to what kind of a car was that, the car that we shot at but no one knew.
No, maybe you misunderstood me, I'll get back to that now.  What kind of clothing did you have on, do you recall how you were dressed, what clothing you had on?
Yes I remember myself but I cannot remember the other comrades clothes.
Do you mind to tell us what you had on?
I was wearing a lumber jacket, that was I was wearing some jacket or coat that was long and I had a hat on my head and I was wearing a pair of jeans and some training shoes.
What kind of a hat was that you had on?
No, it was just an ordinary hat not a balaclava but if you pull it down it can cover the ears.
Do you recall whether any of the other persons who were with you in fact had balaclavas on their heads?
No one was wearing any balaclava but they had some hats on their heads, Ntandaso and Michael, but Tobani had no hat.
Do you recall whether prior to this shooting anyone called out the name of or the nickname of Mr Pro Jack?
No, I never heard any person.
If someone had in fact called out his name would you have heard his name being called?
From the two who were standing with me there I could have heard if someone did make mention of Pro Jack's name.
Did you know Mr Pro Jack personally prior to that incident?
No I did not know Mr Pro Jack at the time, the only person that I knew from that family was Buyiswa Jack.
Now after the shooting where did you say did you go to?
We went to a place that was decided upon, a place where I used to stay, Brown's Farm that is.
And what happened there at Brown's Farm?
I asked the comrades if they knew that car, the car that was standing behind me, no one knew a thing about the car.
I thought those were policemen.  We dispersed and I was left with Tobani and we went to bed.
We saw Michael come with a newspaper reporting that Pro Jack was shot at Lansdowne Road the previous night.

And when Michael in fact said that the person - is it also correct that it was at the same place where you had in fact then fired shots at this particular motor vehicle that you had thought was the police?
And when Michael then came on that morning, the next morning and said to you that the person who had been killed during the shooting was in fact Mr Pro Jack, how did you feel about that?
I was very hurt because it was a mistake as that was not my intention.
What did you then do after the four of you realised then that you had in fact killed Mr Pro Jack?
I told the comrades after reading the newspaper, I told them not to reveal the news to anyone, they must leave it as is.
I knew that they were innocent, I was a perpetrator in this case but they were there as our witnesses.
What did you do then, what happened after that?
On that particular day in the afternoon I decided to go and tell Mr Langa about this incident because I didn't know that I had killed a fellow comrade, I thought I was directing at policemen.
Yes but when you now found out that it was in fact Mr Jack did you then decide to go and tell Mr Langa what had happened?
Yes I couldn't relax after hearing that because it was not my intention to kill my fellow comrades.
Where did you see Mr Langa?
He was in his firm where he used to work.
And why did you go and tell him?
I wanted to reveal this but I was confused, I didn't know where to start but I wanted to get it out of my heart and Pro Jack was also a comrade in the same organisation that I supported.
What was Mr Langa's position within the party at the time?
Mr Langa was a committee leader, I am not sure as to what his portfolio was but he was also a respected person in the community.
After you told Mr Langa what had happened, what did he say to you?
Mr Langa told me not to tell anyone about this, he's going to try some means as to tell the people.
Mr Langa told me that "you are going to see an attorney".
How long was this after the death of Mr Jack?  Approximately, that he came and told you that you were going to see an attorney?
It was not followed but it happened in 1991 but I cannot remember the date and the month.
Apart from Mr Langa and apart from the attorney that you later spoke about this incident to did you tell any other person about this particular shooting of Mr Pro Jack?
I told no one about this incident except Mr Langa and the attorneys because even the ANC people did enquire about it from me but I denied my involvement.
Why did you deny your involvement?
As Mr Langa had told me that to reveal this to other people he was going to find some means to try and tell the people about it.  I wanted to get a go ahead from Mr Langa because ...(intervention)
I was afraid to tell an individual.
Now when you went to the attorneys, who accompanied you?
Now who was Dan Nkwatcho at that point in time?
He was just an MK member from the exile.
And which lawyer did you go and see, which lawyer's firm first of all?
Joshua and Mr Wilkinson who were at Athlone.
The firm then Wilkinson, Joshua, Ghiwala is the firm that you went to go and see, is that right?
When you went there do you recall which of the attorneys you spoke to?
Yes I remember, I spoke to Mr Joshua.
And did you in fact relate to Mr Joshua what had happened?
Just tell us, when you in fact related this story to Mr Joshua, by that time had you already told Dan Nkwatcho what had happened and what your involvement was in the death of Mr Pro Jack?
No, I did not tell him.
And at the time that you in fact spoke to Mr Joshua, who was present in the office when you in fact related the story?
Dan Nkwatcho was present and even when I was taking an oath he was also present.
So you're saying to us that Mr Nkwatcho then heard according to you what had happened on the night that Mr Pro Jack was killed?
Yes he got that from me when we were there in the lawyer's office.
Now after you in fact told the lawyer what had happened, what happened after that?
The Truth Commission came in 1997, Mark Killian, investigating about Pro Jack's death.
Now before we go to Mark Killian and the TRC, after the death of Mr Jack, did you have occasion at any time to speak to any high placed official within the ANC as a result of the death of Mr Jack?

Even when I was in the Transkei, Chris Hani the Chief of Staff asked me about this incident about this firearm, the one that was used killing Pro Jack.  He wanted to know if it was not the very same firearm that was used in killing the police in Khayelitsha but I denied that.
I got scared and it was difficult for me to talk about it because it was not easy for me to do so.
Did you in fact speak to any persons within the ANC investigative unit regarding this particular incident?

Yes, Nswandile Jacobs once called me in the Woodstock offices, asking me about this incident.  I also denied my involvement.  Did you also deny your involvement to
him?
We had an agreement with Mr Langa that I shouldn't tell anyone.  He is the one who is going to tell the ANC about this incident.
Did the lawyers Wilkinson, Joshua and Ghiwala, did they or anyone at that office ever come back to you again prior to you going to the TRC?
Why did you decide then as you say in 1997 to come to the TRC?
I didn't come voluntarily, Mark Killian came to investigate and I was also waiting for a moment when I would get a chance to go and talk about this.
Why was that, why did you want to talk about it?

It's because I was not happy and I couldn't keep it with me any more because it was a mistake and another thing that was worse was the fact that Pro Jack was a fellow comrade therefore I couldn't keep this information any more.
Did anyone, anyone whatsoever instruct you to in fact kill Mr Pro Jack?
No, no one instructed me to do so.
Now when you in fact before going to the TRC did you ever have occasion to speak to the lawyers, Wilkinson, Joshua and Ghiwala again?
No, I made another statement after Mr Joshua's death and I went to Mr Wilkinson and made another statement, same as the one before.
Did you know whether in fact the TRC managed to get hold of the statement that you made to the attorneys?
No, I have no idea about that.
As far as you are concerned, the statement that you made then to the attorney is the same statement that you made to the TRC?
Yes it is the same because I mentioned that I'm taking about here today.
Did Dan Nkwatcho or Mr Langa ever come back to you again and speak to you about what was going to happen or what the ANC had decided as a result of what had happened?
No, not at all.  I've been waiting for them until Mr Langa passed away.
And after he passed away did you ever go and speak to Mr Nkwatcho again?
Now you then went and you spoke to the TRC, you said to us, now is there anything that you want to add about having gone to the TRC and your reasons for coming to the TRC?
The reason for me to come forward, I just want the people to get the truth and they should know that it was a mistake from my side.
Now Mr Yekwani, is there anything today that you would like to say to Mr Pro Jack's mother and his family to in fact express the way that you feel as a result of causing his death?

I can say I feel very bad and Pro Jack was more like a brother to me because we were fellow comrades and I had no intentions to kill him.  If there was an instruction from a particular person I was going to be able to mention the name of that person.  There's nothing to hide when it comes to this case.  I want to tell them that this is the only truth and even the ANC people should know that.
Is there anything else that you want to say, sir?

Thank you Mr Chairperson, there's nothing further.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR RILEY
Thank you Mr Riley.  Mr Yekwani, in the light of what you have said in your evidence, if you known that it was Mr Jack who was driving the vehicle, would you still have fired on the vehicle?
If I knew that the driver was Mr Jack I couldn't have done that because he was a well known comrade but to me I didn't even know him and I didn't even know his car.
Yes, thank you.  Yes, Mr Toyise, is there anything that you wanted to ask Mr Yekwani?

No I have no questions at the moment.
NO QUESTIONS BY MR TOYISE
Thank you very much.  Mr Williams, have you got any questions?
Yes thank you Mr Chairperson.  Mr Chair, can I just confer with Mr Gladstone for half a minute?

Thank you Mr Chairperson.
	Mr Yekwani, before you decided to go and attack the police as you've stated, did you tell Mr Gladstone Ntamo what you were going to do?
No, he knew that whenever I borrow a firearm from him, saying that I was going to patrol he was aware of the fact that I was going to hit the police.
How many times did you actually hit the police?
I can say in Khayelitsha, one incident in Khayelitsha and in Nyanga East.
You told the Committee earlier in your evidence that you told Mr Ntamo that "I used to tell him that I was going to patrol"?
Now did you tell Mr Ntamo after this incident, immediately after the incident that you committed this deed?
No, I didn't tell him, I only told Mr Langa.
Why did you go to Mr Langa when according to your evidence Mr Ntamo was your commander?
I wanted to get some advise, as an elderly person I knew that he some experiences so I wanted to get some advice from him.
Now why didn't you go to your commander, wasn't your commander the best place to get your advice?
It is because I didn't tell him even before the mission.
Yes but according to you he was your commander, so weren't you in terms of the way you operated, weren't you answerable to your commander?
Yes he was a commander but not in the battle field.  I used to recognise the commander only in the battle field not just an ordinary, not a commander like him, I never used to recognise such people.
So are you trying to tell the Committee now that Mr Ntamo wasn't really a commander?
Yes he was a commander but not in the battle field.
I fail to understand your distinction?
Mr Yekwani, who was the commander in the battle field?
At the time I was the commander, at the time of the incident.

Okay, thank you Mr Yekwani.  Now Mr Yekwani, isn't it correct that the one firearm that was in Mr Ntamo's possession was obtained by the community and it was allocated specifically for yourself or to yourself?
And this is then the weapon that you went to fetch by Mr Ntamo?
And is it also correct that on occasion Mr Ntamo asked you if he could borrow the weapon from you for a period of time?
He never used to borrow the firearm from me but I'm the one who used to borrow it from him.
So are you saying that the weapon was allocated to yourself but it was merely kept under the control of Mr Ntamo?

Mr Yekwani, if I understand your evidence correctly, you and your accomplices or the people who were with you that night, you went out there with the specific mission to shoot at the police, is that correct?
Did you know exactly when the police vehicle had passed by the place where you were hiding out?
Yes I knew that the time was ten o'clock but if they were late that would be at least half past ten.
So in other words you expected a police vehicle to pass there between ten and half past ten?
Did other cars make use of that road?
Did a lot of cars use that road or did only a few cars use that road between those times?
Lansdowne Road is a busy road, it's a public road.
Sorry, can I just clarify something with the applicant?  When you wanted to target a police vehicle did you have it in your mind what kind of a police vehicle you wanted to attack?
Yes I knew that a police vehicle is different from private cars.
And what kind of a police vehicle were you targeting?
It was a van, a Cantor.
And what car did the deceased drive on that day?
I did not take note of the colour of the car because when I turned I was disturbed by the light of the car therefore I could not get a chance to see the colour of the car.
What make or type of vehicle did the deceased drive?
Even the make of the car I couldn't see that.
No I did not get that opportunity because we had to cross the road and we started running.
But was it a van or a motor car or what was it?
I think it was not a van it was just a motor car.
It was just an ordinary sedan car, an ordinary vehicle?
It was just an ordinary car with four seats.

Thank you Mr Chairperson, I was going to come to those questions later.  I think the last question I asked you, your answer to that question was that Lansdowne Road was a very busy road.  Do I then take it that you knew that cars were driving up and down that road and that road was indeed very busy?

Now Mr Yekwani, can you tell the Committee where exactly were you and the people that were with you placed?  Did they stand in the road or did they stand next to the road or did they stand under trees?  Where exactly were they located?
We were next to the road, there were trees there but myself and Tobani were placed under the first tree.  Michael and Ntandaso were placed under the second tree.
So in other words you hid yourselves so that -you hid yourself?
Yes, we were hiding because we were waiting for this squad and we did not want to be visible.
So a car driving by innocently wouldn't actually notice you there given the fact that it was misty and you were located in such a way that you hid yourselves?
If the person was driving on the other lane of the road he would be able to see us but he wouldn't be able to see what was in our hands.
Now so in other words cars driving by on the road would also pose no danger to yourself and your friends, no so?
Cars as in ordinary cars except the police cars did not pose any threats or dangers to us.
Mr Yekwani, what I also want to know is from the time that you and your friends came onto that scene, how many cars passed by before you attacked this particular vehicle?
Many car had passed and we could see that those were not the cars that we were waiting for.
Can you then explain to the Committee why this particular car was singled out?
I can say I got a fright and this car did not come from the direction that I was facing.
